ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SEASON PARKING CHARGES IN HDB ESTATES
(Review)


    1. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for National Development whether the

Column: 394

Housing and Development Board will consider reducing the season parking charges in HDB estates for (i) the top level open car parks in multi-storey car parks and (ii) the surface car parks which are located further away from the main HDB estates.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson GRC): Sir, before I ask my question, may I declare that I am a member of the Housing and Development Board. I am asking this question in the general interest of the public. Question No. 1, Sir.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry and the Housing and Development Board are currently reviewing the season parking rates for surface and multi-storey car parks. The review will take into consideration the location and other factors affecting demand for car park lots.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, may I ask the Minister whether, in his review, he is also thinking about the possibility of increasing car park charges which most residents of HDB estates are very concerned about.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have not come to a decision on that matter. I have stated in the past that car park charges must go up over time. But this particular review is to take into account the location of particular car parks, whether it is in the central area or outside the central area, local demand factors, for example, if the demand is very high in a particular area, the rates obviously should be different from the areas where the demand is low and also the type of facility, whether it is an open surface car park or a covered multi-storey car park. So this particular review is meant to take into account specific locational factors. The present approach is to have more or less an uniform rate regardless of where the car park is.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, would the Minister consider inviting the respective town councils to participate in this review?

     Mr Dhanabalan: We will gather data from various sources, including the town councils. But I am not sure whether we can have a formal review involving all the

Column: 395

town councils. I think that will take too long. But certainly the town councils will be consulted when we intend to make big changes.

Column: 395

OLDER HDB ESTATES
(Upgrading of facilities)


    2. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether there are plans to upgrade some facilities in older Housing and Development Board estates to cater to the needs of aging residents.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB will be taking the opportunity under its Upgrading and Redevelopment Programmes to improve facilities in the older HDB estates to cater to the needs of the aging residents. Examples of facilities that will be provided under the Upgrading Programme to meet the needs of the aging residents include:

    (i) provision of external ramps for easy accessibility to the blocks;

    (ii) creation of more landscaped areas to facilitate social interaction among the older residents. In addition, in some blocks, it would also be feasible to provide lift landings on each floor.

    As the Upgrading Programme will span a 10-15 year period, certain improvement works might need to be carried out ahead of the normal schedule for the Upgrading Programme. My Ministry is, therefore, considering expanding the scope of the Community Improvement Projects Committee (CIPC) to allow such improvements to be implemented in advance of the Upgrading Programme.

    In redeveloping older HDB estates, such as Toa Payoh, Bukit Merah and Queenstown, HDB has been adopting a set of comprehensive design guidelines, formulated in consultation with the Ministry of Community Development and other social agencies, and we will design more user-friendly housing blocks and incorporate facilities for older residents. For example, lift landings are provided on every floor in new HDB blocks. Ramps and walkways are

Column: 396

also provided, wherever necessary, to facilitate the mobility of the aged and the handicapped.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, will Tiong Bahru Housing Estate, which is the oldest estate, be considered as a priority under this Upgrading Programme?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, everybody wants priority. I have said that since the Upgrading Programme will take a long time, we will do some of the other types of works under the CIPC programme. It is entirely up to the MPs to put forward suggestions. They know what is allocated for each constituency. They will have to decide what should come first.

Column: 396

NEWTON FOOD CENTRE HAWKERS
(Revocation of licences)


    3. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for the Environment whether the policy to permanently ban hawkers, including their assistants and members of their immediate families, from preparing or selling cooked food at any public or private food centres only applies to Newton Food Centre hawkers whose licences have been revoked.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, any stallholder who repeatedly harasses or overcharges customers will have his licence revoked. After the revocation, the stallholder will not be allowed to operate in any hawker centre owned by Government and statutory boards. His assistants will also be banned from working in these places. These rules apply only to Government and statutory board hawker centres.

    My Ministry has a duty to ensure that customers, both locals and tourists, are not harassed or overcharged by unscrupulous hawkers.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong (Kampong Glam GRC): Sir, does this mean that they can operate in private food centres?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: If there are private outlets willing to employ them, then I say good luck to them.

Column: 397



     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC): Why is it necessary for the Ministry to ban or blacklist those hawkers permanently? Is there no other way of getting those hawkers to improve their behaviour such as by counselling or re-education?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I did not say that these hawkers have been permanently banned. They are banned only insofar as Government and statutory board hawker centres are concerned. My answer to Dr Wong Kwei Cheong is sufficient to answer Mr Chin's concern.

    With regard to counselling, Sir, my Ministry did have several dialogue sessions with the Newton Hawkers' Association to discuss the problem of touting and overcharging by some hawkers in the Centre. The Association agreed with the Ministry's view that action by some errant hawkers may bring disrepute to the Centre concerned. Counselling sessions have also been held, either individually or collectively. During these sessions the hawkers were told to refrain from unscrupulous practices. They were also told in no uncertain terms that if these malpractices persisted, then their licences would be revoked.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: Do the "assistants" also include cooks who are not involved in harassing customers?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, it can be safely assumed that any employee of a hawker stall will know the tactics employed by the employer, in this case, the licensee. Therefore, if he continues to work for the stall and be party to the malpractices, then he should face the consequences.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Is it not true that these touting activities arise as a direct result of the high take-over rentals of these hawkers from another hawker? They have to get the business to cover their rentals. In the first place, hawkers should not be allowed to sublet or sell their licences for an exorbitant fee in which the hawker taking over must recover those heavy expenses.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: I agree with Mr Chiam that it is illegal to sublet or sell the

Column: 398

licence to another party. That is why we are very firm with them.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Then why allow them to sublet?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: It is not allowed. It is illegal, as I said.

Column: 398

PREPARATORY YEAR COURSES IN PRIMARY SCHOOLS
(Objective of pilot project)


    4. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Education what was the objectives behind his Ministry's pilot project of Preparatory Year courses in primary schools; what was the result of the project; and how much was spent in total.

     The Minister for Education (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the objectives of the pilot Preparatory Year project are, firstly, to set a benchmark on the standard of pre-school education for private kindergartens to emulate and, secondly, to develop a well-structured systematic curriculum using multi-media materials and an effective teaching approach which can be adopted by the private kindergartens to provide good pre-school education.

    The project was generally well received. The teachers found the curriculum to be well structured and systematic. The multi-media materials have helped to make lessons more enjoyable and interesting to the children. The parents were generally satisfied with their children's progress.

    A total of $1.3 million has been spent on the development of the Preparatory Year instructional packages in four languages, English, Chinese, Malay and Tamil. This covered manpower cost and the production cost of the trial editions of the PY instructional materials. Production cost for the published editions was met by the co-publisher. These packages as well as the curriculum and teaching methods will benefit many pre-school children when the lessons from the PY project are widely applied.

    About 5,400 pupils were enroled in the PY project in 1990 and 1991. The schools involved incurred a total operating cost of about $14 million over the two years. This

Column: 399

works out to an average cost of about $220 per month per child.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Does the Minister mean that this pilot project is solely for study purposes?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: That is the meaning of the words "pilot project". But it may be useful here if I give Members a bit of the background on the history of how this scheme came about.

    Some Members may recall that in the late 70s many traditional Chinese schools were faced with declining enrolment. The Government therefore introduced pre-primary classes to make work for surplus Chinese language teachers and to arrest the declining enrolment. Despite these measures, the enrolment continued to decline and many of these schools had to close down. A small number of very good Chinese primary schools wanted to teach Chinese at CL1 level. The Government allowed these schools to continue to run their pre-primary classes. They were renamed as Preparatory Year classes and were confined to 10 SAP schools in 1990.

    The Ministry subsequently decided to use the Preparatory Year programme to develop better materials, curriculum and methods for children of all language streams. The pilot programme was therefore extended on a pilot basis to five more SAP schools and 20 non-SAP schools.

    The project has provided useful lessons on how to upgrade the kindergartens. It has also generated overwhelming response from parents. Demand for places far exceeds the number available. It is untenable to continue the project on the present scale. To extend the programme to all primary schools is neither cost effective nor practical. The Government has therefore decided to wind up the pilot project and apply the lessons learnt to help upgrade the private kindergartens.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Does the Minister think that it is justifiable, after spending so much money on this pilot project, to again allocate another $4.2 million to the PAP Community Foundation to carry out another similar project?

Column: 400



     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I explained, the amount of money spent on this programme is not that big. Actually, it amounts to $1.3 million for the purpose of writing up the new teaching materials, developing the new curriculum, providing new worksheets and teaching methods. This money is not wasted. It can be applied to all the private kindergartens and I expect it will be applied very widely in due course.

    As for the upgrading of the PAP kindergartens, it is part of the Government's effort to help upgrade private kindergartens. So we should not grudge it and deny our young children the opportunity to learn in a better environment using better methods. It is our intention to continue to upgrade the kindergartens for the benefit of our children.

Column: 400

ALEXANDRA HOSPITAL
(Service and staffing level)


    5. Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Minister for Health what is his appraisal of the service level at Alexandra Hospital and whether he is satisfied with the service provided to the public at the present staffing level in the hospital.

     The Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, Alexandra Hospital (AH) is a medium sized 400-bedded acute general hospital. It has departments of general medicine, general surgery, orthopaedics and paediatrics. It also has a 24-hour accident and emergency service.

    Alexandra Hospital has been able to improve its facilities and level of service in recent years. It is now comparable to the other Government hospitals.

    Let me list out some of the improvements. Alexandra Hospital now has 89 doctors, compared to only 66 doctors five years ago. This is an increase of over 35%. Patients, especially those with complex medical problems, can now obtain a much higher level of medical care. Alexandra Hospital has a total staff strength of 882, giving a staffing ratio of 2.2 per bed. This is comparable to the other general hospitals as well.

Column: 401



    The hospital has also been upgrading its equipment and operating systems. It recently installed new X-ray equipment costing $0.5 million. This has resulted in a shorter waiting time for patients.

    Alexandra Hospital has computerised its patient registration, billing and appointment scheduling. It has also improved its Accident & Emergency and Specialist Outpatient Departments.

    Sir, all these improvements have enabled Alexandra Hospital to provide a more efficient and faster service to patients. For example, at the A&E Department, 75% of all patients were seen within 53 minutes in 1989. In 1991, this was shortened to only 27 minutes. A&E patients have to generally wait longer in the other hospitals.

    Similarly, in the Specialist Outpatient Clinics, 75% of all patients are now seen within 40 minutes, compared to 50 minutes in 1989. In the other hospitals, the waiting time varies from 40 to 70 minutes.

    The median waiting period for patients requesting for an appointment to see a specialist has been reduced from 11 days in 1990 to 3-6 days in 1991. In the other hospitals, the median waiting period varies from 7 to 14 days, which is much longer.

    Patients are now happier with the medical and nursing care, meals and ward accommodation provided by Alexandra Hospital. Patient surveys show that 74-94% of patients rate these services as excellent or good, compared to only 60-88% in 1987.

    As a result, more patients are now using Alexandra Hospital. In 1991, the number of hospital admissions increased by 4% to 19,700, while the Specialist Outpatient Clinic attendances increased by 8% to 64,100.

    Sir, my Ministry is continuing to upgrade Alexandra Hospital. We are now undertaking major physical upgrading works in Alexandra Hospital costing $18.2 million. This will enable us to provide more B2 wards, and better ward facilities. We will upgrade the operating theatres, add a day surgery suite, and expand the

Column: 402

Intensive Care Unit. There will also be facilities for geriatric patients. All these will help to improve the level of service to patients in Alexandra Hospital even further.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen: Sir, would not the Minister agree that if there are reported cases of patients who are prematurely discharged, even in Alexandra Hospital, with all these improvements, there is still room for improvement?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, there is always room for improvement in any hospital. The question is to what extent. Normally, the doctors will vet all patients carefully and ensure that they are suitable for discharge. Of course, patients may prefer to stay longer in the hospital, especially in the Class C wards where the charges are very low, rather than be discharged home or into a nursing home where they may have to pay even more. They will then consider themselves to be prematurely discharged, but actually they are well enough and do not require to be kept in an acute hospital which is really meant to cater for people with acute illnesses.

ROAD TAX AND DIESEL TAX
(Change in basis of computation)


    The following question stood in the name of Mr Lew Syn Pau --

    6. To ask the Minister for Communications whether he will consider changing the basis of computation of road tax for cars and diesel tax for taxis from a monthly to a daily one.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen: Question No. 6, Sir.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Sir, the Ministry of Communications and the Ministry of Finance have agreed to compute the road tax and diesel tax for all vehicles, including taxis, on a daily instead of monthly basis. This change will result in revenue loss estimated at $2.5 million per annum.

    The change in the basis of computation requires an amendment to be made to the Customs Act to enable the Minister for Finance to make rules to pro-rate the collection of diesel tax. The Minister for

Column: 403

Finance will be introducing a Bill in Parliament soon to amend the Customs Act.

EVENING AREA LICENSING SCHEME
(Removal)


    7. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for Communications whether fewer vehicles are entering the Central Business District in the evenings, with the completion of the Central Expressway, and if his Ministry will consider removing the evening Area Licensing Scheme.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the traffic counts that were conducted by the Public Works Department, before and after the opening of the Central Expressway Tunnels, showed no change in the volume of traffic entering the Restricted Zone during the evening restricted hours between
4.30 pm and 6.30 pm. There is therefore no reason to remove the evening ALS.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, although the Minister said that the study has shown that there is no change in the traffic counts, for people who come in and out of the CBD in the evening, their impression is that there is indeed a lessening of the traffic volume. On that basis, would the Minister consider shortening the hours of the ALS in the evening?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: The PWD and the Registry of Vehicles will continue to monitor the traffic situation. So far, the counts which have been done on a random basis show that there is no change in the pattern, but I can assure the Member that we will continue with these investigations into the traffic patterns.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, may I ask the Minister whether his Ministry will also consider taking off the ALS evening restriction for certain periods as a trial to see whether there are any changes actually in the traffic pattern, and whether the evening ALS will be lifted if the traffic is tolerable?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Under special circumstances, the Ministry has actually made certain changes to the evening ALS. In fact, there was a recent case when the eve of the Lunar New Year fell on a Monday

Column: 404

which we predicted would have some effect on the pattern of traffic in the evening. And for that reason we did make a special case for removing the evening ALS during that time. But until such special circumstances occur, I see no reason why we need to change a system which has proven effective in controlling congestion, which was the original objective of the evening ALS.

Column: 404

SALE OF COMMERCIAL/SHOP UNITS
IN PUBLIC HOUSING ESTATES
(For use as offices of MPs/political parties' branch offices)


    8. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board is planning to sell commercial and/or shop units in public housing estates for use as constituency offices of Members of Parliament and/or political parties' branch offices.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, shops in the HDB estates provide goods and services needed by residents. At present, HDB sells new shops in housing estates which are under development. The Planning Authority generally allows these shops to be used for service and retail purposes. MPs can tender for HDB shops and commercial premises for use as MPs' offices if the change of use is approved by the Planning Authority.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, I have two supplementary questions. (1) Can MPs apply to buy shops now before their offices are demolished in September? (2) Will change of use be granted when they purchase these commercial premises?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, MPs can of course bid whenever shops are put out for sale. So they should keep a look out and look at the newspapers. When HDB puts out shops for sale they can make their bids.

    As to whether change of use would be allowed, this really depends on where the shops are. I would say that in the majority of cases it would be allowed. MPs can always check with the Planning Authority before they make their bid.

VOID DECK AT BLOCK 316,
HOUGANG AVE 7
(Use of converted space)


    9. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for National Development what is the proposed use of the converted space at the void deck of Block 316, Hougang Avenue 7 and when the conversion was completed.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, the conversion of part of the void deck space at Block 316, Hougang Avenue 7 was completed in 1990, at the request of the former Advisor to the Punggol Citizens' Consultative Committee (CCC) and the Residents' Committees (RCs). It was to be used as a Senior Citizens' Recreation Centre. It has since been taken up by the present Advisor to the Hougang CCC and RCs for use as a Senior Citizens' Club.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: When was the allocation made?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, the allocation was made in November 1991.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Why was the converted space at the void deck left vacant for such a long time? And the HDB suddenly discovers that there is a lack of void deck space after I wrote in on 10th September 1991 to request that the converted space be allocated to me for use as an MP's office.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, as I said, it was converted at the request of the Advisor at that time for use as a recreation centre for the senior citizens. For various reasons, the Advisor then decided to have the centre somewhere else. But it was in fact converted for use by the community. And when the MP asked for the same space to be used as an MP's office, we did not allocate it because, as all MPs know, the provision of MPs' offices by the HDB will terminate in September this year. So there is no point in allocating this space and taking it back again in September if a more permanent use could be found; and we have found a more permanent use. As far as the MP is concerned, we have asked him to identify some void deck space
